question.title: Will Mike Pence be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Mike Pence is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are evaluating several forecasting questions related to Elon Musk's potential appearance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference and the recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module by 2050. 

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This event is likely influenced by Musk's past engagements and his interest in Bitcoin. Given his involvement in the cryptocurrency space, I would assign a moderate probability to this event, estimating it to be around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35. 

3. **para_P (Possibility of Elon Musk attending)**: This is similar to P and should have the same probability, so I would also set this at 0.65.

4. **Q (Apollo 10's Lunar Module recovery by 2050)**: The recovery of such an artifact is uncertain due to the challenges of locating and retrieving it. Given the historical significance and the ongoing efforts, I would assign a probability of 0.30 to this event.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occurring)**: This probability would be the product of the individual probabilities of P and Q if we assume they are independent events. Therefore, P_and_Q = P * Q = 0.65 * 0.30 = 0.195.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurring)**: This can be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Here, it would be 0.65 + 0.30 - 0.195 = 0.755.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Apollo 10's Lunar Module recovery and Musk not showing up)**: This would require both events to happen independently. Assuming independence, it would be Q * not_P = 0.30 * 0.35 = 0.105.

8. **Q_given_P (Apollo 10's Lunar Module recovery given Musk shows up)**: This is a conditional probability. If Musk shows up, it may influence the probability of the Module's recovery positively, so I would estimate this to be higher than Q, perhaps around 0.40.

In summary, the events are interrelated, with P and Q being independent in terms of their occurrence, but the conditional probabilities suggest that one event may influence the likelihood of the other. I will now proceed to output the probability estimates based on this reasoning.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee and Mike Pence not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following occur: (a) Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (b) Mike Pence is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will either Mike Pence or Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Mike Pence or Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee and Nikki Haley not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Nikki Haley is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It will resolve as **No** if either Donald Trump is not selected or Nikki Haley is selected. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will either Nikki Haley or Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Nikki Haley or Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are evaluating predictions about two distinct events: Elon Musk's attendance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference and the recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module by 2050. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: This prediction will depend on various factors, including Elon Musk's schedule and interest in attending the conference. Given his previous engagements and influence in the cryptocurrency space, I might estimate a moderate to high probability that he will attend, say around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is the complement of P, and should logically be around 0.35, as it directly relates to the probability of P.

3. **para_P (Possibility of attendance)**: This is closely related to P and should have a similar probability estimate, perhaps slightly higher if we consider it as a more general question about the possibility of his attendance, say around 0.70.

4. **Q (Recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module)**: This event is more uncertain due to the historical and technical challenges involved in recovering a spacecraft from interplanetary space. I might estimate a lower probability for this, around 0.20.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occur)**: This is a conjunction of the two events. Since both events are independent, I would estimate this as the product of their probabilities, approximately 0.65 * 0.20 = 0.13.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurs)**: This would be the sum of the individual probabilities minus the conjunction, so it would be around 0.65 + 0.20 - 0.13 = 0.72.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Recovery of Lunar Module and Musk does not show up)**: This would also be independent, and I would estimate it as Q * not_P = 0.20 * 0.35 = 0.07.

8. **Q_given_P (Recovery given Musk shows up)**: This conditional probability would likely be similar to Q, as Musk's attendance may not significantly influence the recovery of the Lunar Module, so I might keep it around 0.20.

In summary, the relationship between P and Q is that they are independent events, which allows for straightforward calculations of conjunctions and disjunctions. The estimates should also adhere to the consistency rules provided.

question.title: Will Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and Nikki Haley not be the nominee?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Nikki Haley is not selected as the nominee. If both conditions are met, the question resolves as **Yes**; otherwise, it resolves as **No**.

This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will either Nikki Haley or Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Nikki Haley or Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: This event is highly dependent on Musk's schedule and interest in Bitcoin events. Given his previous involvement with cryptocurrencies, I estimate a moderate probability of him attending, around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk not showing up)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35.

3. **para_P (Possibility of attending)**: This is essentially the same as P, as it asks if there is a possibility of him attending. Therefore, I would assign it the same probability of 0.65.

4. **Q (Recovery of Apollo 10's Lunar Module)**: The recovery of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is uncertain due to its unknown location and the challenges involved in such a recovery. I would estimate a lower probability of 0.30 for this event.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occurring)**: The likelihood of both events happening is the product of their independent probabilities, so I would estimate this to be around 0.195 (0.65 * 0.30).

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurring)**: This is calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. Given the probabilities, I would estimate this to be around 0.725.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Apollo 10 recovered while Musk does not show up)**: This is a more specific scenario that combines Q with not_P. Given the probabilities, I would estimate this to be 0.105 (0.30 * 0.35).

8. **Q_given_P (Recovery given Musk shows up)**: This conditional probability would likely be higher than the general probability of Q since Musk's presence might influence the recovery efforts positively. I would estimate this at around 0.40.

**Independence**: The events P and Q are not directly related; Musk's attendance at the conference does not affect the recovery of the Lunar Module. However, they are still evaluated together in the context of P_and_Q and P_or_Q. 

Overall, I will ensure that all probability estimates adhere to the consistency rules provided, adjusting any values as necessary to maintain mathematical integrity.

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is contingent on Elon Musk's attendance, which may depend on various factors such as his schedule, interest in Bitcoin, and the significance of the conference. Given his previous involvement with Bitcoin and cryptocurrency, I would estimate a moderate to high probability of him attending, say around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If I estimate P at 0.65, then not_P would naturally be 1 - 0.65 = 0.35.

3. **para_P (Is there a possibility that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is closely related to P, so I would give it a similar probability, perhaps slightly higher due to the phrasing suggesting a possibility rather than certainty. I could estimate this at 0.70.

4. **Q (Will Apollo 10's Lunar Module be recovered by 2050?)**: The recovery of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is a complex event that depends on various factors, including technological advancements and funding for space exploration. Given the uncertainties, I would estimate this probability at around 0.40.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both occur: Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and the Lunar Module is recovered by 2050?)**: This event requires both P and Q to be true. Assuming independence, I would calculate this as P * Q = 0.65 * 0.40 = 0.26.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 or the Lunar Module be recovered by 2050?)**: This can be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q. Using the estimates, this would be 0.65 + 0.40 - 0.26 = 0.79.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Elon Musk shows up, will the Lunar Module be recovered by 2050?)**: This is a conditional probability, which could be estimated based on the assumption that if Elon Musk attends the conference, there may be more interest in space exploration. I might estimate this at 0.50.

question.title: Will Larry Elder be the Republican nominee and Glenn Youngkin not be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Glenn Youngkin is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

question.title: Will either Glenn Youngkin or Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Glenn Youngkin or Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we have two primary events: (1) whether Elon Musk will show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (P) and (2) whether the Apollo 10 Lunar Module will be recovered by 2050 (Q). These events are independent of one another, meaning the occurrence of one does not directly affect the likelihood of the other. 

1. **P (Elon Musk showing up)**: This event's probability will be influenced by factors such as his schedule, interest in Bitcoin, and potential commitments. Given his previous involvement in the crypto space, I estimate a moderate probability of 0.60 for this event. 

2. **not_P**: This is simply the complement of P, which would be 1 - P, leading to a probability of 0.40.

3. **para_P**: This question is essentially a rephrasing of P, so it should have the same probability estimate of 0.60.

4. **Q (Apollo 10 Lunar Module recovery)**: This event is highly uncertain due to the challenges of space recovery and the unknown location of the module. I estimate a low probability of 0.20 for this event based on historical context and current efforts.

5. **P_and_Q**: The probability that both events occur can be estimated by multiplying their independent probabilities, leading to P_and_Q = P * Q = 0.60 * 0.20 = 0.12.

6. **P_or_Q**: The probability that at least one of the events occurs can be calculated using the formula P_or_Q = P + Q - P_and_Q, which gives us 0.60 + 0.20 - 0.12 = 0.68.

7. **Q_and_not_P**: This event captures the scenario where the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is recovered, but Elon Musk does not show up. This can be estimated as Q * not_P = 0.20 * 0.40 = 0.08.

8. **Q_given_P**: This conditional probability reflects the likelihood that the Lunar Module will be recovered if Elon Musk shows up. Given the independence of these events, I might estimate Q_given_P to be similar to Q, so I would estimate it at 0.20.

Overall, the relationships and independence of these events allow for straightforward calculations of probabilities while adhering to the consistency rules.

question.title: Will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election and Donald Trump Jr. not be the nominee?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and (2) Donald Trump Jr. is not selected as the nominee. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently considered; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

In this scenario, we are evaluating the likelihood of two events: (1) whether Elon Musk will show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference, and (2) whether the Apollo 10 Lunar Module will be recovered by 2050. 

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: Given Musk's high profile and previous involvement in the cryptocurrency space, I estimate a moderate probability that he will attend the conference. Factors influencing this include his schedule, public interest, and potential benefits of his appearance. 

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is estimated at 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35. 

3. **para_P (Possibility of Musk attending)**: This is likely to be similar to P, as it essentially asks the same question but in a slightly different phrasing. I estimate this to be around 0.65 as well.

4. **Q (Apollo 10 Lunar Module recovery)**: The recovery of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is a more uncertain event. Given the historical significance and the challenges of locating and recovering space artifacts, I estimate a lower probability for this event, around 0.30.

5. **P_and_Q (Both events occur)**: The joint occurrence of both events is likely to be lower than either event occurring individually, as they are independent. I estimate this to be around 0.15.

6. **P_or_Q (Either event occurs)**: This should be higher than either individual probability but less than the sum of both, due to the intersection of both events. I estimate this to be around 0.75.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Apollo 10 recovered and Musk does not show up)**: This scenario combines the recovery of the Lunar Module with Musk's absence, which is plausible. I estimate this at around 0.10.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up, will the Lunar Module be recovered)**: The occurrence of Musk showing up may influence the perception of the Lunar Module recovery, but it does not directly affect the probability. I estimate this to be around 0.25.

In summary, the events are somewhat independent, with P and Q not directly affecting each other's outcomes. The estimates provided will need to be checked against the consistency rules.

question.title: Will either Donald Trump Jr. or Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either Donald Trump Jr. or Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

The Lunar Module flown on Apollo 10 is the only flown lunar module which didn't end up crashing into the Moon or burning up in Earth's atmosphere.
After 'dress rehearsal' testing in lunar orbit, during which the Lunar Module came within 8.4 nautical miles of the lunar surface, the ascent engine performed a burn to depletion which sent the craft into interplanetary space and the vehicle is currently in a heliocentric orbit. The location of the Apollo 10 Lunar Module is unknown as of May 2019, but efforts are underway to find it.
As a unique historical artefact from the original golden age of human spaceflight, this Lunar Module would certainly make for an interesting museum exhibit.

The relationship between these events is important for calculating the probabilities of combined events such as P_and_Q, P_or_Q, and Q_and_not_P.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up)**: Given Musk's high-profile nature and previous involvement in Bitcoin, I estimate a moderate probability that he will attend the conference, likely around 0.65.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up)**: This is simply the complement of P, calculated as 1 - P, which would be 0.35.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given P occurs)**: This is a conditional probability. If Musk does attend, it may affect the likelihood of the Lunar Module being recovered, but not significantly. I would estimate this to be around 0.45.
